Award.AwardTitle: New, GK-12 Connections in the Classroom: Molecules to Muscles (C2M2)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of Connections in the Classroom: Molecules to Muscles (C2M2) is to enhance graduate fellows' communication and teaching skills in an interdisciplinary research and education setting. The interdisciplinary research theme ?molecules to muscles? is used as a vehicle to increase relevancy of science coursework to high school students by relating research advances in areas important to them (i.e. sports, soldier protection), while fellows will gain the ability to communicate to non-scientific audiences and researchers outside their field through an interdisciplinary team approach. Research improving human performance transcends the boundaries of individual scientific disciplines and requires seamless communication between biologists, chemists, biochemists, materials scientists and engineers. Eight fellows will be recruited each year from the College of Science and Technology to work with HS science teachers to develop and deliver classroom activities based on fellows? research, ranging from polymer composites for sporting equipment to biochemical processes of respiration. Fellows, teachers and high school students will gain appreciation for the integrative nature of scientific advancements through a unique interdisciplinary approach. C2M2 will impact a diverse group of fellows, teachers and HS students with the goal of developing future scientific leaders. Mississippi ranks 49th in participation in the high-tech industry and has the highest percentage African American population, a segment particularly underrepresented in advanced STEM degrees and careers, and The University of Southern Mississippi hosts a one-third minority student population. Results will be disseminated through a web-site, publications and presentations at education and scientific conferences. Industry support will help sustain GK-12 activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The GK-12 Molecules to Muscles graduate fellowship program at The University of Southern Mississippi paired doctoral students in polymer science and engineering, chemistry and biochemistry, and biological sciences with high school teachers at seven local high schools (high minority and free and reduced lunch districts).  Graduate fellows served as “scientists in the classroom” ten hours per week for 9th -12th grade classes in biology, microbiology, environmental science, chemistry, genetics, anatomy and physiology, physics, and polymer science, where they developed lectures, activities and laboratory experiments based on their graduate research.  Fellows also served as mentors for high school student science fair projects and after-school research.  Graduate students gained experience communicating to broad audiences, teachers gained content knowledge and exposure to state-of-the-art research, and high school students learned the impact of science and engineering on daily life. Over the five years of the program, 35 graduate fellows, 17 high school teachers, and over 2200 high school students were impacted, with overwhelmingly positive feedback.  Of the GK-12 fellows who have graduated, 100% have gained employment in their field of choice (industry, government lab, or academia), and all expressed gains in communication and teaching skills.  To date 98 presentations at technical conferences and 32 refereed publications have resulted. The "Communicating Science" workshop developed as part of the program has been institutionalized and is offered to all graduate students in the College of Science and Technology. Interactions with participating high school teachers and districts will be sustained through the Research Experience in Engineering and Computer Science Site for Sustainable Polymer Engineering Research, field trips to campus supported by the departments, summer activities for K-12 students, and outreach by graduate students.
